column4: i have a sendmail setup from an gentoo server i want to migrate to ubuntu server. i already have 2 proper .mc files to generate 2 sendmail.cf's but i can't seem to figure out how to integrate them with the ubuntu startscripts or its /etc/mail/sendmail.conf :(
m4
mc files are a script for the processor m4, you need to convert them to .cf files.  and you do this with the command m4
i know, i already got them, my prob is the init.d script of ubuntu
what is the problem you have with the init script?
do you mean its starting an MTA and a MSA?  that is your conf file, one recives email the other sends it
yep thats whats it's probably doing. but it's not starting the 2nd process the way i want (with -C/etc/mail/sendmail-rx.cf) as extra options

its supposed to do that.  the process that you think of, sendmail is on half of the smtp archtecture.  When your email client sends mail (when you do) you connect to one part, it then tells the other part to pass that mail on.  Its suposed to be like that, its part of the architecture, its part of security, and its supposed to be like that
that isnt a ubuntu thing btw its a smtp and sendmail thing
have a look -> http://pastie.org/521539
what about it?
do you mean you want to have the init script use those? change them to sendmail.cf and submit.cf
exactly, the config part of sendmail is perfectly fine. just the starting/stoppting via the init script is my prob
either rename sendmail-rx.cf to submit.cf or change the init script
as for the queue options you have to change those as well, altho the only thing I notice that inst normal is the log level
s.th. different. any idea why "killall -9 sendmail" doesnt work on ubuntu?
killall means kill with process signal 9 (SIGKILL) all processes named sendmail.  Not processes named sendmail.real, sendma or anything EXCEPT sendmail
killall is baiscly a sledge hammer of last resort. And surely not a nice way to hand processes
so when i have "root      6674  0.0  0.8   8848  2060 ?        Ss   09:12   0:00 sendmail: accepting connections"
use /etc/init.d/sendmail stop to stop sendmail
killall -9 sendmail-mta did indeed work, would've been nice to see the correct processname in ps :S
dont use it, it would be a good way to loose email
